summary: This document is an email chain from June 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing how to handle Touhy requests (requests for government information in third-party litigation) from victims of Jeffrey Epstein involved in civil suits. It details internal deliberations on procedures, jurisdictional issues with other districts (SDFL, NDGA), and the handling of requests from victims' counsel, including Roberta Kaplan.

persons.name: Roberta Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney representing an Epstein victim making a Touhy request for documents; referenced as receiving the standard Touhy process letter.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the investigations and civil litigation; victims are seeking documents related to him.

persons.name: Geoff
persons.context: Referred to as the 'responsible' U.S. Attorney who might receive a Touhy-referred subpoena from another district.

connections.description: Kaplan is legal counsel for a victim bringing civil litigation against Epstein's estate, seeking government documents related to Epstein.

events.title: Production of documents to Epstein victim
events.description: The SDNY office produced documents responsive to an Epstein victim's Touhy request about a month prior to this email.

events.title: Follow-up request from victims' counsel
events.description: Victims' counsel made a lengthy list of follow-up questions and additional demands after the initial document production, which the office largely declined to fulfill.

keyFacts: The SDNY possesses FBI investigative files from the SDFL Epstein investigation but deliberately avoided obtaining any files from the SDFL U.S. Attorney's Office to avoid conflict and discovery issues.
NDGA has stepped into the shoes of SDFL for Epstein-related matters, and victims may be directed to submit document requests there.
Internal debate centered on whether SDNY, as the district where the civil action was filed, was the 'responsible' USA for Touhy requests regarding the SDFL investigation materials.
The office cited the law enforcement privilege and ongoing investigation as reasons for not producing certain additional materials sought by victims' counsel.
